div.head: President Lincoln's Address at Gettysburg
div.p:
The consecration of the Soldiers' Cemetery at Gettysburg, Pa., took place on the 10th of Nobermber. It was a day that will long live in the memory of those who winessed the inspiring demon-errssious of the occasion.The Oration of Edward Everett was, as all his orations are, exceedingly appropritate and elegant. It required two hours for ist delivery, but no intelligent hearer is over **** for MR.Everett to close; as there were 30,000 and 50,000 present, it is hardly to be expected that all were hearers, however. He usually speaks without notes, *eelling from memory the longest addre**, yet with such perfect free-dom of manner that the closest observer would never **** that his sentences were not born of the moment and entirely extemporaneous. After the oration and a dirge by a choir from the M**** Association of Baltimore, President Lincoin ** introduced. We have room to-day for little farther notice of the conseration exercises than to copy entire the President's speech. Of course it was short,pithy and pra*****.
He said:

Four scores and seven years ago our fathers established upon this continent a government subscribed in liberty and dedicated to the fundamental principles that all men are created equal by a good God. [Applause] . Now we are engaged in a great conte*!--- the question whetherthis nation, any nation, so conse-*** **, so e****, can long remain. We are met on a great ****** of the war; we are met here to dedi-cate a portion of that field as the *** resting place of those hwo have given their *** that the *** ***** might live. It is all right, *** and proper, that we should do this- but in a larger sense, we cannot dedicate- we cannot consecrated- we cannot hallow this ground. The brave and self-sacrificing men, living and dead, who struggled here, have consecrated it far above our power to add or to de-tract[Great applause] It is for us, rather-the living -be *** and here to the unfin-ished work that they have thus far so nobly carried forward. ["Good" and great applause.] It is better for us to be dedicated to the great task remaining be-fore us: for **** our d devotion to that cause for which they gave the full measure of their devotion. Here let us resolve that what they have done shall not have b*** done in vain; that the nation shall, under Gove, have a new birth; that the Government of the people; founded by the people, shall not perish.
